text.headline: The first neural network: The perceptron
text.text:
The perceptron is one of the first implementations of a binary classifier for supervised learning. It was developed by Frankk Rosenblatt (It was invented in 1943 by Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts.)
It is considered one of the first neural networks

text.headline: The introduction of expert systems
text.text: Domain-specific, rule-based systems replicate human experts in domains like medicine or finance. The term "expert-systems" was coined by Edward Feigenbaum (left, Stanford Heuristic Programming Project) and he is sometimes named the "father of expert systems."

media.caption: Example classification tree of a medical screening test. Positive test results are often of less predictive value than expected when the class in question occurs rarely.
media.credit: Created by Hansj√∂rg Neth with https://riskyr.org/

text.headline: Classification and Regression trees (CART)
text.text: In the late 1980s and early 1990s new methods became popular. One such method were classification and regression trees (CART). The term was first introduced by Breiman et al. in 1984 and refers to trees that classify discrete categories (classification) or continuous variables (regression).

media.caption: A brief explanation of support vector machines (SVM)

text.headline: The development of support vector machines (SVM)
text.text: Support Vector Machines are an algorithm for supervised classification. They were developed at AT&T Bell Laboratories by Vladimir Vapnik and colleagues.

media.caption: Example of a random forest
media.credit: By TseKiChun - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=112433454

text.headline: Introducing random forests
text.text: Random forests are an ensemble-based classification method using the output of multiple decision trees. The class that is selected by the algorithm is the class that is selected by a majority of trees. They were introduced in 1995 by Tin Kam Ho.

media.caption: Representing images on multiple layers of abstraction in deep learning
media.credit: By Sven Behnke - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=82466022

text.headline: Introduction of deep learning to artificial neural networks
text.text: Deep learning algorithms rely on multiple layers of neural networks to identify higher-level features of the input. Although the term Deep Learning was introduced to the machine learning community by Rina Dechter in 1986, it was introduced to artificial neural networks by Igor Aizenberg and colleagues in 2000. Since then it gained increasing popularity, also because of the increase in computational resources in the 2010s.
